thread.title: Warren Buffett Has a Bigger GDP Than These 15 Countries
thread.title_full: Warren Buffett Has a Bigger GDP Than These 15 Countries

author: Holly Hammersmith
title: Warren Buffett Has a Bigger GDP Than These 15 Countries
text:
By Holly Hammersmith July 14, 2015 
Warren Buffett is known as one of the wealthiest people in the world. Many people follow his story, support his journey to wealth and mimic his ideology – and for good reason – as of July 2015, Buffett’s net worth was valued at close to $67 billion, according to Forbes.com. 
Related: Warren Buffett’s 14 Best Tips for the Class of 2015 Who Is Warren Buffett? 
The feisty 84-year-old is a self-made billionaire and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway , a Nebraska, Omaha-based American multinational conglomerate holding company. The company’s Class A stock is more expensive than that of any other U.S.-based company atmore than $200,000 per share. 
Buffett has been a long-time member of the list of the top 10 wealthiest individuals in the world. In addition to being a highly successful businessman, he is an active investor and philanthropist. Despite his vast wealth, Buffett adheres to his personal values and strives to live frugally. 
Buffett’s incredibly high net worth is bigger than the gross domestic product — the total value of goods and services tallied over a specific period — of some countries. Check out this list and be inspired in your own journey toward personal wealth. Click image to view full size 1. Uzbekistan – $63 billion 
Uzbekistan, a Central Asian country, is hot, dry and landlocked, but crops are huge here – in particular, cotton. Uzbekistan is the world’s fifth-largest exporter of cotton and sixth-largest producer. 2. Kenya – $61 billion 
Kenya serves as the economic hub and transportation center for East Africa. Many residents work at least part-time in agriculture, helping to produce tea and coffee. 3. Luxembourg – $60 billion 
Luxembourg is dominated by service industries, particularly finance, but the small Western European country has diversified to include chemicals, machinery and equipment, rubber and automotive components. 4. Guatemala – $59 billion 
A third of the people in Guatemala, Central America’s most populous country, work in agriculture, exporting sugar, coffee, bananas and vegetable. T extiles and clothing are also important industries, and remittances from Guatemalans abroad amount to a tenth of its GDP. 5. Croatia – $57 billion 
The economy of this Eastern European country took a dive during the 1991-95 war and is slowly coming back, largely helped by tourism. Other industries in Croatia include electronics, textiles, shipbuilding and petroleum products. 
Read: 11 Companies You Would Never Guess Warren Buffett Loves 6. Uruguay – $57 billion 
A well-educated workforce in this South American country exports soybeans, rice and wheat. Major industries in Uruguay include food processing, electrical machinery and transportation equipment . 7. Bulgaria – $56 billion 
This Eastern European country, with land on the Black Sea and the famous Danube River, counts energy sources such as electricity, water, gas and petroleum products among its industries. Corruption and crime hamper its prospects. 8. Ethiopia – $55 billion 
Ethiopia’s economy is based on agriculture with coffee huge for its 94 million residents. The government of this East African nation is pushing to diversify into manufacturing, textiles and energy generation . 9. Costa Rica – $50 billion 
While bananas, coffee, sugar and beef are still the backbone of exports for Costa Rica, this Central American country has expanded into industrial and specialized agricultural products, such as medical devices. 10. Slovenia – $49 billion 
Unemployment remains high in this Central European country, despite varied industries , such as ferrous metallurgy and aluminum products, lead and zinc smelting and electronics. 11. Lithuania – $48 billion 
This Baltic country, which joined the European Union in January, has a fast-growing economy, thanks to diverse industries, such as appliance manufacturing, shipbuilding and video game development. 12. Tunisia – $47 billion 
Key exports from this North African country include textiles and apparel, food products, petroleum products, chemicals and phosphates. Its economy faces multiple challenges following its 2011 revolution. 
Keep Reading: 7 Investing Mistakes Warren Buffett Regrets 13. Lebanon – $46 billion 
The economy of this Mideast country is service-oriented; main growth sectors include banking and tourism. Its 1975-90 civil war halved its national output, and economic growth is tamped today by refugees from the Syrian civil war. 14. Serbia – $44 billion 
Exports from the country, in Europe’s Balkan Peninsula, include automobiles, base metals and chemicals. 15. Ghana – $39 billion 
Agriculture accounts for nearly one-quarter of GDP and employs more than half of the workforce of this African country. Gold and cocoa exports and individual remittances are major sources of foreign exchange. 
GDPs are rounded to nearest billion in U.S. dollars and are as of 2014 from The World Bank, except 2013 for Luxembourg and Tunisia . Exports and industry information from the Central Intelligence Agency .
